text:
Chambers and Hudson Streets, West Side, at point of intersection, with Broadway looking Southwards.

W

1860

Irving Underhill, Photographer,
New York City.

120 Chambers Street, south side, east of West Broadway, showing the 5-story structure occupied by J. Newton Van Ness Company. See No. 50 Warren Street for the other side of this structure that has entrances on both streets.

May 19, 1905.

Wurtz Brothers.

50 Warren Street, north side, east of West Broadway, showing a 5-story structure that extends through the block and has an entrance on Chambers Street, for which see No. 120 Chambers Street.

May 19, 1905.

Wurtz Brothers.

88 West Broadway, adjoining the S. W. corner of Chambers Street, showing the lower portions of a 5-story loft building at this location.

October 15, 1914

Wurts Brothers

88 West Broadway, adjoining the S. W. corner of Chambers Street. Shown is the elevation of a 5-story loft structure at this location.

October 15, 1914

Wurts Brothers

#88 West Broadway, showing the courtyard walls of that building.

October 10th, 1914

Wurts Brothers, Photographers,

(1) At the convergence of Hudson Street (left) and West Broadway (right), looking northward from Reade Street. The 6-story building at the apex bears Nos. 114-116 Reade Street, 24 Hudson Street and 110-116 West Broadway. Also shown is the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line on the latter Street. July 2, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, at a later date, showing the Western Union Building on Thomas Street, between Hudson Street and West Broadway (former site of the R.C. Williams warehouses). February 11, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, Hudson Street and West Broadway at point of intersection. May 4, 1941.
P.L. Sperr,

(1) At the convergence of Hudson Street (left) and West Broadway (right), looking northward from Reade Street. The 6-story building at the apex bears Nos. 114-116 Reade Street, 24 Hudson Street and 110-116 West Broadway. Also shown is the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line on the latter Street. July 2, 1928.

(1) At the convergence of Hudson Street (left) and West Broadway (right), looking northward from Reade Street. The 6-story building at the apex bears Nos. 114-116 Reade Street, 24 Hudson Street and 110-116 West Broadway. Also shown is the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line on the latter Street. July 2, 1928.

Thompson Street, West Side, and Broadway, between Canal and Grand Streets. Interior of St. Alphonsus, R.C. Church, showing altar.

B. Hellmich, Photographer,
82 W. Broadway.

About 1930

(1)
An aerial view of 129-117 Chambers Street, at, adjoining, and east of the N.E. corner of West Broadway. The view also shows West Broadway, east side, from Chambers to Reade Streets.
February 11, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
117-129 Chambers Street, east of, adjoining, and at the N.E. corner of West Broadway. No. 129 is the Cosmopolitan Hotel.
April 19, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
An aerial view of 129-117 Chambers Street, at, adjoining, and east of the N.E. corner of West Broadway. The view also shows West Broadway, east side, from Chambers to Reade Streets.
February 11, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
117-129 Chambers Street, east of, adjoining, and at the N.E. corner of West Broadway. No. 129 is the Cosmopolitan Hotel.
April 19, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Chambers Street, north side, east from West Broadway, The Cosmopolitan Hotel (No. 129) is at the N.E. corner of West Broadway.

April 29, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

West Broadway, east side, at Chambers Street, and showing the Cosmopolitan Hotel (the N.E. corner), across the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line. Prominent building shown, is the Woolworth Tower.

December 25, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

This hotel is about 80 years old, and was the rendezvous of politicians, judges and lawyers. Its owner for many years was the late Joseph M. Weintraub. See the New York Times, November 12, 1937 for an account of a fire that swept the upper floors on the 11th.
